oracle_info.speaker: John Griffiths AM
oracle_info.content: Welcome, everyone, to this meeting of the Children, Young People and Education Committee.

oracle_info.speaker: John Griffiths AM
oracle_info.content: We will move on then to item 2 on our agenda, the continuation of our inquiry into targeted funding to improve educational outcomes, and evidence session 8.

oracle_info.speaker: Llyr Gruffydd AM
oracle_info.content: I just want to start by asking about your perception of how schools are using the pupil development grant funding, and to what extent they are genuinely targeting that funding exclusively towards children eligible for free school meals.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: They are tracking progress of pupils, they are trying to improve attendance, they are trying to work with families and the community in general, they're doing work specifically to improve how children are doing in exams, in key stage 4, specifically—a lot of funding is being spent on that—improving the confidence of students, taking students on extra-curricular activities, improving literacy and numeracy.

oracle_info.speaker: Mark Reckless AM
oracle_info.content: I just wanted to ask about the more able and talented stream.

oracle_info.speaker: Mark Reckless AM
oracle_info.content: It was good to read in your report an increased emphasis on this and to see your awareness of its importance in the PDG as well.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: Well, I think Estyn has always been very strongly focused on improving the performance of more able pupils.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: So, we feel that getting the curriculum right, tailoring the curriculum to the needs of the pupils in that area, and improving teaching, is a more sustainable long-term solution.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: I think there is a general consensus about the benefits of the foundation phase.

oracle_info.speaker: Michelle Brown AM
oracle_info.content: To what extent has the rate of improvement differed between the primary and secondary sectors?

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: Generally, there is a widening of gaps when you go from primary to secondary, but also it's from foundation phase to key stage 2 to key stage 3 to key stage 4.

specific_query_list.query: How was the effectiveness of the pupil development grant funding?

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: This grant has been targeted far better by now than it was originally.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: At the start of this grant, the funding was often spent on tackling underachievement, rather than dealing with the underachievement of children who are eligible for free school meals specifically.

oracle_info.speaker: Llyr Gruffydd AM
oracle_info.content: Because the research by Ipsos MORI and the Wales Institute of Social and Economic Research, Data and Methods has shown that there is some kind of blurring—I think that's the term that they use—in terms of who is eligible.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: So, I think that schools are perhaps not following that exactly, but within the spirit of the grant, I think I’m fairly comfortable.

specific_query_list.query: What was emphasized on the more able and talented stream?

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: Well, I think Estyn has always been very strongly focused on improving the performance of more able pupils.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: It's a particular part of our inspection framework—looking at the relative performance of different groups.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: So, we look at the different performance of boys and girls, free school meals and non-free school meals, ethnic minorities, but we also look at the performance of more able pupils in particular, and we question schools about how they provide for the more able pupils, and we've referred to Seren in several of our inspection reports.

oracle_info.speaker: Claire Morgan
oracle_info.content: Throughout our inspections, we are looking for best practice, because part of our strategy is always to identify where there are weaknesses, but actually to point schools in the direction of where they can find a solution.

oracle_info.speaker: Claire Morgan
oracle_info.content: So, capturing different approaches to more able and talented is part of the role of inspection.

specific_query_list.query: What was the proportion of schools making effective use of the PDG?

oracle_info.speaker: Michelle Brown AM
oracle_info.content: You've reported that the proportion of schools making effective use of the PDG remains around two thirds of secondary and primary schools, meaning that a third are still not using that PDG effectively.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: I think that sort of proportion broadly corresponds to the schools that don't have particularly good leadership.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: So, schools do a lot of things that they are in control of—the things I mentioned earlier: things like improving attendance, offering extra-curricular activities, literacy and numeracy support, tracking pupils—all those sorts of things.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: But an important element of this, I think, is engaging with the learners, but also with parents and the community.

specific_query_list.query: What did the PDG come into working with families?

oracle_info.speaker: Claire Morgan
oracle_info.content: Often, in the best schools, the headteachers consider themselves to be community leaders as well as headteachers, and they often set up arrangements where they engage directly with the families of disadvantaged children or children who are underachieving generally.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: And where does the PDG come into this, and the use of it?

oracle_info.speaker: Claire Morgan
oracle_info.content: This sometimes is used for appointing staff whose role it is to facilitate these arrangements to give one-to-one support to children, to monitor attendance, to visit homes where children are not coming into schools, to try and address what the barriers are in getting them into classrooms.

specific_query_list.query: How did the government plan to spread the method of building connections?

oracle_info.speaker: Claire Morgan
oracle_info.content: Obviously, the first thing we do is the inspection report, and we highlight the practice there.

oracle_info.speaker: Claire Morgan
oracle_info.content: This is an example of our best-practice case studies.

oracle_info.speaker: Claire Morgan
oracle_info.content: We also have conferences as well, where we invite the headteachers from those schools to come and present to other headteachers.

oracle_info.speaker: Hefin David AM
oracle_info.content: It doesn't seem very engaging.

oracle_info.speaker: Claire Morgan
oracle_info.content: So, it is actually schools learning from other schools, and I think the work that the consortia have been doing on school-to-school support as well can contribute to it.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting talk about the attainment gap between pupils on free school meals and those not on free school meals?

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: It's quite difficult to identify the cause and the effect in terms of the PDG.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: Whether you say that that is due to PDG or not is quite difficult, but there have been some improvements.

oracle_info.speaker: Michelle Brown AM
oracle_info.content: In 2017, we saw a re-widening of the attainment gap between pupils on free school meals and those not on free school meals.

oracle_info.speaker: Michelle Brown AM
oracle_info.content: What effect do you think the Welsh Government's changes to performance measures have had in terms of impact?

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: I think there's a growing realisation that secondary schools, key stage 4, is driven overly by performance indicators, and, whatever performance indicator you come up with, there will be unintended consequences.

specific_query_list.query: What were the reasons for Professor Donaldson being asked to undertake a review of Estyn's role?

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: I think any good organisation would welcome external scrutiny.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: There have been in the past systems of quinquennial reviews.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: I think it is healthy for anybody to have that sort of external view, and I think in particular we're proud in Estyn that we are a body that is developing and trying new things and evolving continuously.

specific_query_list.query: What were the benefits to Wales of having an independent body for inspecting?

oracle_info.speaker: Mark Reckless AM
oracle_info.content: What have been the biggest benefits to Wales of having Estyn as an independent body inspecting schools and other institutions in Wales compared to the work that Ofsted has done in England?

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: Well, we have very good relationships with Ofsted and with Education Scotland and the Education Training Inspectorate in Northern Ireland.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: I wouldn't like to compare—I don't think it would be fair to compare ourselves.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: We do things slightly differently, but we benefit a lot from each other.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: I think one of the things we've done and we've developed over many years is the use of the nominee and peer inspectors in particular.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting discuss about the lack of good practice being able to travel into all parts of Wales?

oracle_info.speaker: Darren Millar AM
oracle_info.content: I mean, one of the problems that I know you've identified in the past is this lack of good practice being able to travel into all parts of Wales, and, of course, we've got local authorities, we've got regional consortia, we've got the Welsh Government—all of which want to see good practice replicated where possible.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: I mean, specifically to do with foundation phase, there is a foundation phase—I can't remember what it's called now—excellence network I think, which is being relaunched.

oracle_info.speaker: Claire Morgan
oracle_info.content: Because of the lack of training and maybe the confidence to pursue that active and experiential learning approach, teachers have tended to resort to what they feel more comfortable with, which is more of an adult-led learning—often still high quality, but it doesn't ensure that the learners become far more independent, far more engaged in their learning.

specific_query_list.query: What was the way to get families and the community more involved in education?

oracle_info.speaker: John Griffiths AM
oracle_info.content: Quite a lot of what we discussed earlier was around the importance of getting families and the community more involved in education, and one way of doing that, I think, is through community-focused schools that are very much accessible to the community, linked well with outside organisations, having an extended school-day offer.

oracle_info.speaker: John Griffiths AM
oracle_info.content: We have the twenty-first century schools programme, but we have a lot of schools existing that haven't been part of that.

oracle_info.speaker: John Griffiths AM
oracle_info.content: I just wondered to what extent Estyn might encourage or highlight the need to encourage greater consistency in community-focused schools across Wales, because I think there is a feeling that it is very inconsistent.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: Yes, we would very much be happy to support anything like that.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: I think there was a bit of a misunderstanding about the term 'community-focused school'.

oracle_info.speaker: John Griffiths AM
oracle_info.content: So, if there might be a mechanism that could have community-focused schools working in the way that you've described right across Wales, would Estyn be in favour of such a mechanism?

specific_query_list.query: To what extent had the rate of improvement differed between the primary and secondary sectors?

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: I'm not sure if there's been a difference in the rate of improvement, but certainly I've raised in this annual report, and indeed in previous annual reports, the difference between primary and secondary.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: We've got 7 in 10—nearly three quarters—of primary schools doing well and about half of secondary schools.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: There are several reasons, I think.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: Generally, there is a widening of gaps when you go from primary to secondary, but also it's from foundation phase to key stage 2 to key stage 3 to key stage 4.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: So, I think there is a whole range of issues that explains or goes part way to explaining what you've identified.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting discuss about the standards in special schools?

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: Yes, we highlighted special schools as a successful sector in the annual report, as we have over many years.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: Over 90 per cent of them are good or better.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: The small number of schools that don't do quite as well tend to be the schools that deal with children with emotional and behavioural difficulties.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: But the sector as a whole is a good example of sharing good practice.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: They work very, very well together.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: Possibly they don't have an overlap in catchment areas, they're quite geographically separate, so they don't feel as if they're in competition with one another.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: So, we have seen improvement in that independent special sector over the cycle.

oracle_info.speaker: Meilyr Rowlands
oracle_info.content: That's partly down to the work we do in Estyn.
